• What binary is, and why it runs everything

  • 2025 June 26
  • Back to HQ

Imagine it’s Friday morning and you're reading the news on your laptop, then, suddenly, you wonder...

"How is all this data on my screen displayed to me in the right form?”

That’s binary.

At the end of this blog you know exactly why binary is used in computer science and gets the right data on your screen.

In decimal, we count using digits 0 to 9. In binary, we only have 0 and 1, to represent all numbers and data by combining powers of two. Binary is the foundation of computer systems and digital communication.

CPUs use binary in logic gates; you can see each logic gate as a mathematical function, you have input, logic, output. The core gates are AND, OR, and NOT. If we combine these we can create more complex logic gates like XOR, NAND, and 2 more. All these logic gates follow boolean algebra and are built using transistors.

A transistor acts like a digital switch:

  • 1 = Electricity flows (on)
  • 0 = no flow (off)

If you’re reading this blog from your macbook with a K2 chip then your chip contains ~20 Billion transistors, communicating on/off so you can read the right message from your screen.

Each on/off switch is called a bit (1 or 0). “Each bit has a weight. From the right to left, their values are: 20, 21, 22, 23, up to, 27 (in an 8-bit byte).”

What this means is that through logic gates, mathematical operations, and transistors within your CPU groups 8 bits called into one byte. With a byte we can create 256 unique combinations.

Enough to represent characters, colors, numbers, and more.

To give you an example, ‘01000001’ is in binary for the number ‘65’ in decimal (base-10), and maps to the capital letter ‘A’ in ASCII (which stands for the American Standard Code for Information Interchange).
